üìò Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

1. Introduction and Motivation

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are fundamental concepts in linear algebra with applications in many areas of mathematics, physics, and engineering. They describe special directions in which a linear mapping has a particularly simple effect.

What are Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors?

An eigenvector of a matrix A is a non-zero vector v that, when multiplied by A, is only stretched or compressed. The associated stretching factor Œª is called an eigenvalue.

2. Definition and Properties

Formal Definition

Let A be an n√ón matrix. A scalar Œª is called an eigenvalue of A if there exists a vector v ‚â† 0 such that:

$$A\vec{v} = \lambda\vec{v}$$

The vector v is then called an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue Œª.

Important Properties

1. Characteristic Equation

$$\det(A - \lambda I) = 0$$

The eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial.

2. Eigenspace

$$E_\lambda = \{\vec{v} \mid A\vec{v} = \lambda\vec{v}\}$$

The set of all eigenvectors corresponding to an eigenvalue Œª forms a subspace.

3. Geometric Multiplicity

The geometric multiplicity of an eigenvalue is the dimension of its corresponding eigenspace.

4. Algebraic Multiplicity

The algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue is its multiplicity as a root of the characteristic polynomial.

3. Calculation of Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

3.1 2√ó2 Matrix

For a 2√ó2 matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$$

the characteristic polynomial is:

$$\det(A - \lambda I) = \lambda^2 - (a+d)\lambda + (ad-bc) = 0$$

Example

Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Characteristic polynomial:

$$\det(A - \lambda I) = \begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda & 1 \\ 1 & 2-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = (2-\lambda)^2 - 1 = \lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 3 = 0$$

2. Roots:

$$\lambda_1 = 1, \lambda_2 = 3$$

3. Eigenvectors:

For Œª‚ÇÅ = 1:

$$(A - I)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution: v‚ÇÅ = (1, -1)·µÄ

For Œª‚ÇÇ = 3:

$$(A - 3I)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution: v‚ÇÇ = (1, 1)·µÄ

3.2 3√ó3 Matrix

For a 3√ó3 matrix, the characteristic polynomial is calculated by expanding along a row or column.

Example

Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Characteristic polynomial:

$$\det(A - \lambda I) = \begin{vmatrix} 2-\lambda & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3-\lambda & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 3-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = (2-\lambda)((3-\lambda)^2 - 1) = 0$$

2. Roots:

$$\lambda_1 = 2, \lambda_2 = 2, \lambda_3 = 4$$

3. Eigenvectors:

For Œª‚ÇÅ,‚ÇÇ = 2:

$$(A - 2I)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution: v‚ÇÅ = (1, 0, 0)·µÄ, v‚ÇÇ = (0, 1, -1)·µÄ

For Œª‚ÇÉ = 4:

$$(A - 4I)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution: v‚ÇÉ = (0, 1, 1)·µÄ

3.3 Diagonalizability

A matrix A is diagonalizable if there exists an invertible matrix P such that:

$$P^{-1}AP = D$$

where D is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal elements are the eigenvalues of A.

Example

Diagonalize the matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Eigenvalues: Œª‚ÇÅ = 1, Œª‚ÇÇ = 3

2. Eigenvectors: v‚ÇÅ = (1, -1)·µÄ, v‚ÇÇ = (1, 1)·µÄ

3. Transformation matrix:

$$P = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, P^{-1} = \frac{1}{2}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

4. Diagonal matrix:

$$D = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$$

4. Special Matrices

4.1 Symmetric Matrices

For symmetric matrices:

  • All eigenvalues are real
  • Eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are orthogonal
  • The matrix is diagonalizable

Example

Examine the matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Eigenvalues: Œª‚ÇÅ = -1, Œª‚ÇÇ = 3

2. Eigenvectors: v‚ÇÅ = (1, -1)·µÄ, v‚ÇÇ = (1, 1)·µÄ

3. Orthogonality: v‚ÇÅ·µÄv‚ÇÇ = 0

4.2 Orthogonal Matrices

For orthogonal matrices:

  • All eigenvalues have magnitude 1
  • Eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are orthogonal

Example

Examine the matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Eigenvalues: Œª‚ÇÅ = e^iŒ∏, Œª‚ÇÇ = e^-iŒ∏

2. Eigenvectors: v‚ÇÅ = (1, i)·µÄ, v‚ÇÇ = (1, -i)·µÄ

5. Applications

5.1 Principal Axis Transformation

Diagonalization allows quadratic forms to be transformed to principal axes.

Example

Transform the quadratic form:

$$Q(x,y) = 2x^2 + 2xy + 2y^2$$

Solution:

1. Matrix of the quadratic form:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$

2. Eigenvalues: Œª‚ÇÅ = 1, Œª‚ÇÇ = 3

3. Transformed form:

$$Q(x',y') = x'^2 + 3y'^2$$

5.2 Stability Analysis

The eigenvalues of a matrix provide information about the stability of a dynamical system.

Example

Analyze the stability of the system:

$$\begin{cases} \dot{x} = -x + y \\ \dot{y} = x - 2y \end{cases}$$

Solution:

1. System matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$$

2. Eigenvalues: Œª‚ÇÅ = -2.618, Œª‚ÇÇ = -0.382

3. The system is stable because all eigenvalues are negative.

5.3 Vibration Problems

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors describe the natural frequencies and vibration modes of a system.

Example

Calculate the natural frequencies of a spring-mass system:

$$\begin{pmatrix} m_1 & 0 \\ 0 & m_2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} \ddot{x}_1 \\ \ddot{x}_2 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} k_1+k_2 & -k_2 \\ -k_2 & k_2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Eigenvalues of the matrix K/M give the squared natural frequencies

2. Eigenvectors describe the vibration modes

6. Summary

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are important concepts in linear algebra with diverse applications.

Important Properties:

  • Characteristic equation
  • Eigenspaces
  • Geometric and algebraic multiplicity
  • Diagonalizability

Calculation Methods:

Applications:

  • Stability analysis
